The good is really good.  The design is gorgeous from the bar to the restaurant to the lobby to the rooms – everywhere, everything is contemporary and stunning.  Clean lines, sleek and bright.  Often the lobbies of high-end hotels are stunning and then the room falls down (Dream Downtown).  Not the case here.  We were in Room 812 – king sized bed, gigantic (by Manhattan standards) shower and great closet space.  The bathroom had a flat screen built into the mirror.  You can see that the spent a lot of money on mouldings and finishing work.

We went to the bar at night – great crowd, a good mix, young people, established people, gay, straight – well dressed, sophisticated.  Cocktails were terrific and the service was spot on.

And then it fell down a bit.   As the check-in clerk was showing us the room, we noticed that the Crestron system was not working – which is a bit of a problem since the entire room is tied to the Crestron remote.  She said someone would be up within the hour to fix or replace the remote.  We went out for a walk, had lunch, came back – and it wasn’t fixed.  I went downstairs as we were on our way out for the night and asked again if someone could have a look at it.  I was assured they would.

No one ever came and it was never fixed.

Worse yet, the TV’s – in the main bedroom and in the bathroom – would randomly turn on at 4 or 5 in the morning with intensely high volume that all had to be shut down manually.  Not a total disaster but given their price point – not good news either.

While the bathrooms were impressive by New York hotel standards, there is design flaw they need to figure out.  The seal at the top of the shower is too tight and doesn't allow the air to circulate - the upshot being a moldy smell that takes away from the luxurious design.

The other issue was street noise.  Wow.  I am pretty durable by New York standards.  I lived there for twenty years.  I get it.  But this was pretty disturbing.  We were on the 77th Street side of the Mark (which I thought might be quieter than the Madison Avenue side).  If that was the case, I can only imagine the Madison Avenue side.  If you decide to make a reservation – definitely ask about noise and request a “quiet room” if one exists.

Would I stay there again?  Maybe.  It has the potential to be an amazing addition to the luxury hotels on the upper east side – but again – given their price point, it needs to be flawless and it’s not.

title: Great location, service & loaner bikes!
text: Enjoyed a long weekend at The Mark. Wonderful service, a great location & loaner bikes to enjoy Central Park.  Not inexpensive but good value.

title: Probably one of the best hotels in NY
text:
We (a family with 2 children) spent 5 days at The Mark. It was phantastic. The building offers you all the electronic equipment that you want. B&O TV, very nice furniture. The hotel stuff makes you feel all the time like a real guest, they are always very friendly and are organizing everything you want to (cards for museum, Taxi, Restaurants ...). The Restaurant in the hotel is very good! 
What else: gym in hotel is very good.
The location of The mark is very good, in a quiet little street between the Central Park and Madison Avenue, within walking distance to the hot-spots of the city (for example 20 min. to the Apple Cube) and only 2 minutes to Central Park!
I can recommend The Mark, on our next trip to NY we will stay again in this hotel.

title: A Fantastic Weekend At The Mark
text:
We recently had a wonderful stay at The Mark. Aesthetically, the hotel is extremely elegant and sophisticated. The service was also fabulous. The staff was friendly and professional. They personalized our experience upon check in by making us smile in the elevator and while giving us the detailed tour of our room. The next morning, we ordered room service from The Mark Restaurant. Everything was perfect and it was delivered on time. The table that was brought in was set up right by one of our windows. We enjoyed the view while eating our delicious breakfast. 
The Mark is a perfect alternative to any of the busier hotels in midtown. It's quiet and spacious, whereas many other New York City hotels fail to give guests that much needed break from the "hustle and bustle" The Mark did just that. Since our first trip, we've recommended the hotel to our close friends and they had a very similar pleasant experience. We can't wait to stay at The Mark Hotel again.

title: A nice alternative to mid-town
text: I've stayed here several times for business. The upper East Side location was a little inconvenient for a rash of mid-town and downtown meetings, but the trade-off was having a different kind of experience. There's a more personal and relaxed feel here that is missing in the typical high-end business-oriented properties. Staff is friendly. Rooms have tons of great amenities, including extra walk-in closets off the bathroom and vanishing TVs in the over-sink mirrors... great for bath time! Glass ceiling in the restaurant makes breakfast very pleasant. Smallish in feel, in the New York way.

title: Séjour de rêve
text:
Bonjour a tous,

Ne cherchez plus le meilleur de NY, il s'agit définitivement du Mark.

Tout n'y est que goût, élégance et attentions.

L'équipe est attentionnée sans pour autant être too much et menée avec élégance par un jeune directeur français charmant.

Les autres palaces de NY ont du pain sur la planche pour tenir la distance.

Bravo!

title: Wonderful Stay at The Mark
text: We recently had a fabulous stay at The Mark hotel. Everything from the service to the rooms to the aesthetics of the hotel was perfect. Aesthetically, the hotel is beautiful, elegant, and sophisticated. Located on a beautiful and quiet tree-lined street on the Upper East Sid, it is removed from the hustle and bustle of the city and within walking distance to some of the best shops and museums in NYC. The staff was very professional, friendly, and provided great hospitality. The room was clean, spacious, and the bathroom was large and included some great amenities. As an individual, who has stayed in many hotels all over the world, I would highly recommend The Mark to anyone visiting NYC!

title: Expensive but worth it.
text: Fantastic service, lovely rooms, nice location, and sadly in this day and age if you want any kind of service you have to pay for it, no point paying for a sub standard 4 star, might as well pull up a bit more and get treated properly, in lovely surrounding, nice bar area.

title: The Mark was awesome!
text:
My husband and I stayed at The Mark Hotel April 4th & 5th, 2012.  It is located in the tony upper east side.  Great designer shops in the area, good restaurants & delis.  Our room was lovely & very roomy, and completely equipped with a great mini bar, in- room ice maker, cocktail glasses, drinking glasses, complimentaryl bottled water each evening.  Turn- down service, complimentary robes & slippers, ample closet space, and a large bathroom with both tub & shower.  Free WiFi, with a desk and a couple of comfy chairs in the room.

Situated in a quiet neighborhood ( Murray Hill), so sleep was peaceful, with no traffic or night noise.  That, coupled with very a comfortable King bed, contributed greatly to our comfort and good night's sleep each night.

The hotel is relatively small and intimate.  Their bar seemed to be very popular, but we did not go inside, as we aren't much for drinking.  The concierge was very helpful and helped us to get the complimentary tickets to visit the World Trade Center Memorial.  There is no cost, but you must have reservations, and you cannot get tickets on the site.

We really enjoyed our stay, and breakfast was included, so that represented a great value, and you could order odd a menu, so lots of selection, which we enjoyed.  The service was top notch, and we would definitely say there again.

This is notmthemplace to,stay if you want to be within walking distance to Times Square,or mid-town, but we walked only 2 blocks to catch the subway, which was only 2 stops from 42nd street, and it was very cheap and easy.

The Mark has a couple of complimentary limos available to guests on a first-close basis, from 3PM leo 10:00PM, butmwemwere never able to,get one.  The door man was very adept at getting us a taxi when we needed it, and all the employees were very friendly and helpful.

All in all, we really enjoyedmourmstay at The Mark, and would definitely go back!

title: What a let down... Such a shame.
text:
I recently booked 3 nights accommodation at The Mark. I have been to NYC many, many times, normally staying downtown at the likes of: The Bowery; Soho Grand; Mercer etc. On this trip I decided it might be nice to do something totally different for the first few nights of my 12 day stay and book a good hotel uptown or on the Upper East side. After a fair amount of research on the similar hotels in this area, which hold a 5 star rating akin to The Mark, I decided to go ahead and book a Madison King Room. I have pretty high standards when it comes to hotels, travel a decent amount and I work in an artistic field so therefore apart from basic requirements deemed necessary in a hotel such as; good service, quiet rooms, bed quality, cleanliness etc., I am personally always very drawn to the small design details and décor of a hotel, therefore based on what I saw from The Mark website and its status as one of NYC's nicest and most luxurious hotels, it looked beautiful to me and I very much looked forward to staying.

My husband and I flew in from the West Coast after flying from Sydney (20+ hours of travel) and arrived at The Mark at around 8.30pm on a very rainy Sunday night. The desk staff were nice enough, no major faults there, although honestly there is a somewhat snotty, pretentious feel about the place. It's fine if you like that sort of atmosphere (which I realise is all part of that 'UES NY' atmosphere and was half expecting it) but we found it a tad cold and insipid, it lacks warmth. You can still do 'refined UES' but be less wooden and stiff about it if that's the main agenda at your establishment due to the neighbourhood you are located in.. It all just comes across painfully stereotypical and rather boring. 

We checked into our room and waited for about 20 minutes for our bags to be brought up. I was very impressed with the cleanliness of the room, the design was lovely, very stylish and it was spotless, as was the bathroom. Literally gleaming and it had a very cosy, glamorous and comfortable feel. The mini bar was good and wonderfully there was a large freezer section full of ice – so during your stay you have ice 'on-tap' so-to-speak ~ one feature I loved. We headed downstairs to meet a colleague for a drinks in the hotel bar then retired to the room and booked some room service food.

This is where it all when majorly downhill. Whilst I was waiting for the food I decided to take a deep bath, I was shattered after all the travel, the bath was great, great that is until I went to unplug it. After several attempts on both my husband's part and mine, we surmised it was totally broken and we'd have to call reception for them to organise a plumber. (BTW the plug in the sink was totally blocked too). A plumber was sent up at around 11.30pm who set about trying to fix the bath. At 12.45am he was still there and unable to fix the plug, so was shovelling bucket loads of my bath water into the shower, the room was a mess. Following this we got 40 minutes of incessant loud banging as he went at the plug with a crowbar (or what sounded like something similar). It was 15 mins into this stage that my husband went to the front desk to say we would need to be moved to another room as we were unable to get to bed for the previous almost 2 hours due to said hammering in bathroom at almost 2am. 

Whilst my husband was at the front desk he received a very flippant and disinterested attitude from the receptionist. He asked that we were moved as it was getting onto 2am and we needed to get some sleep. He was told there were no rooms available other than one smaller than the one we had paid for and if we moved that's where we would be for our 3 days stay. They also told him the hotel was otherwise fully booked for the Monday and Tuesday – call me a cynic, but on a Monday and Tuesday night in early April in this area, I am instinctually feeling this was a lie. Also when I checked online in the room from my laptop, every form of room from a Madison King to their Penthouse was available to book… (Why on earth don't hotels cop on to that fact guests can tell when they are lying about room availability by simply checking online ?!!). During my husband's time downstairs the plumber (a really nice guy BTW) came into my room, dripping in sweat from all his efforts saying it was totally unfixable and he wasn't sure how he could fix it the next day either.

I was pretty disgusted at this attitude from the front desk. Fair enough if we were in a 1 or 2 star hotel, but their entire attitude was snotty and cold and totally unacceptable for the level of hotel they claim to be. Had she said; "I am so sorry we are full tonight, would you mind staying in the room or the smaller one and out of courtesy we will move you to a better or same level room tomorrow?" that would have been utterly fine, also, we were very unimpressed that she never checked with the plumber after 15 or 20 mins to see how things were going as she would have been aware we were hanging around waiting for him to fix it. 

We decided to stay the night and check out the following day as I'm not interested in forking out money to hotels who blatantly show they don't give a fiddlers about you unless you are paying for their Presidential suite. When my husband ventured down again to tell reception we would be leaving the following morning he was met with a stunned 'rabbit caught in headlights' stare from both female and male receptionists, who suddenly started pleading was there "Anything at all they could possibly do?", "Could we upgrade you to a better room tomorrow sir??!" What a joke, 30 minutes previous we were told there were "no other rooms available" other than a pokey lower level one. The following morning upon checking out we were asked how we enjoyed our stay? When we replied 'Very disappointed" yet again, another 'rabbit caught in headlights stare' from the morning staff who then mentioned "was there some issue with your bath plug, I see a brief note here, I am so sorry, next time please come and stay with us and I will ensure you are upgraded"… The whole way they handled themselves was almost embarrassing esp. when they claim to be 5 star. 

When we decided on the Sunday night at 2am to leave, I booked a room immediately at The Greenwich Hotel in TriBeCa and we moved there first thing Monday morning. Which, within second of walking into, was warm, inviting, friendly, cosy, incredibly decorated and totally welcoming, they have service and details down-pat. In hindsight I was actually totally delighted The Mark treated us the way they did as if not, I wouldn't have moved hotels and had a wonderful 2 night stay there will 100% return to The Greenwich on my next NYC trip. It is without a doubt the best hotel I have ever stayed at in New York. 

On an end note, if you do decided to stay at The Mark… a tip, book a room away from Madison Ave, during our one and only night stay, I must add the room was crazy noisy, at around 5.30 or 6am we were awoken by the irritating, high-pitched, repetitive beeping noise of a truck reversing, or maybe it was a bus as it happened about 6 or 7 times between this time and 8am… aka zero sleep from 6am onwards. Fantastic when we only got to bed 4 hours earlier. In addition this was only made my annoying in addition to the loud humming all night long of the air conditioning unit which were found utterly impossible to turn off. 

Really disappointing overall and a really awful way to start a long anticipated break away in NYC.

title: Disappointing
text:
The mark has nice rooms and very friendly and attentive staff in the registration and the lobby. However, we were disappointed to be waken up by a 4:00pm visit from a guy who was checking the minibar, not knowing that we just checked in, tired and snoozing for a few minutes. Furthermore, a bellman tried to get into the elevator (which is the size of a small closet) while four other people were there... Trying very hard until I asked him to wait for the next elevator...

When we mentioned the unscheduled afternoon visit to the staff downstairs we got the Perfinctory "we a very sorry." response. At this level of hotel, one would have expected the staff to have more authority to "make things right." disappointing.

title: Perfect New York City Hotel
text: We stayed at the Mark Hotel with our children to celebrate mom's fiftieth birthday. We booked two Madison King suites and could't have been more delighted. They are joined by a separate foyer which can be used privately when both rooms are used by the same guests. We loved the new bathrooms, the Sub Zero mini-bar systems, the technology "tablet" that operates just about everything (including the curtains) and the spaciousness of the rooms. The Mark has a long history of guests from "old wealth," but knows instinctively how to meet the needs of a cliental that includes a great deal of recent diversity. The wonderful bar and the Jean Georges restaurant add to a gracious and luxurious stay.

title: The Mark of Excellence
text: We spent five sterling nights in April at the Mark on the Upper East Side (UES) of Manhattan.  It was in a word 'superb'.  Check in was quick and easy and they have at least five folks standing at the entrance during busy periods to ensure all is running smoothly.  We signed up for the Leaders Club and booked the room through them.  I highly recommend you do this if you are staying any more than two nights.  The $60 allowance for the breakfast in the morning covers down on most of your meal.  I do say most of your meal as the room service prices are pretty intense and we rarely stayed under that figure for breakfast for two (oatmeal is $14).  We were getting married in the city on the 19th and were met in our room by a bottle of chilled Taittinger and a welcoming note from the manager.  Leaders club also scored us an upgrade to a Madison King.  As some of you may be aware, NYC is notorious for small hotel rooms.  This is not the case for the Mark.  The rooms are quite expansive and very newly renovated.  WiFi is complimentary (as far as something can be complimentary for $545.00 per night ;-]...).  The tub is huge, and I mean huge.  It easily accommodated two six foot guys and we availed ourselves of it most evenings. All the room amenities are very cool.  The only thing I would critique is the lack of a full length mirror in the living space (they do have one on the inside of the sliding door to the bathroom, but it gets a little warm in there and closing the door to tie a tie was a pain).  Every person we encountered was nice and asked if we need anything.  We did not take advantage of the concierge, but they were always there if needed. We went to the bar on our last evening and the folks there are just wonderful.  We had a party of six and they got us in and out quickly as we were going to Cafe Boulud for dinner (incredible, that place.)  Best drink was the Rhubarb Hibiscus Cosmopolitan; try one! The location on the UES was absolutely perfect.  It is far enough away from the tourists in mid-town to make you feel like a local as you walk among the top 1% income crowd.  You will note the uniform for the UES is skinny, skinny with discrete Chanel or some other designer and skin stretched tight on those of a certain age (and we are not just talking the ladies...)  The Mark does not have views per se, but it's always interesting to watch that UES crowd strolling by from your window. Overall you would be hard pressed to find a better place to alight than here in NYC.  Spend the extra dollars, you will not be disappointed.
